In Northern New Jersey and the City of New York--areas with a long and rich mass transit history--various kinds of new connections will enable existing transit systems to operate more efficiently.  In other sections of the country where recently opened rail systems are proving to be extremely popular, selected expansion will enable these systems to tap new markets.  In still other cases, cities will be constructing their very first fixed guideway transit project.   Last year's  Report to Our Customers  told of the FTA's executing the largest single full-funding grant agreement in the agency's history, $1.5 billion in federal dollars alone to continue construction of the Red Line subway project in Los Angeles.  This year's report follows up on that accomplishment by pointing out that recent months have seen another record-setting performance, the execution of more full-funding grant agreements than ever before.      IMPROVING CUSTOMER SERVICE     Over the past year, the FTA has made many important changes in the  day-to-day management of its grant program , changes that are intended to make the program more responsive to the needs of its customers.     Electronic grant-making:   something that was identified in last year's  Report to Our Customers  as an experimental pilot project has quickly expanded into a routine way of  doing business.  Over the past year, 22 grantees received  60 grant awards (for almost $1 billion) electronically.  By the end of next year, it is expected that all FTA grantees will be able to use this new system for post-award grant management milestone tracking, with ten new grantees per region phased in for electronic grant submission.   Timely grant payments:   funds are now typically deposited in a grantee's bank account  within 1.5 days  from the time an electronic request for payment is made.  Buy America:   significant streamlining was implemented in the enforcement of "Buy America" regulations.  Grantees now have a blanket waiver from "Buy America" requirements  for any procurements with a dollar value under $100,000.     Spare parts eligible for capital assistance:   the law has long allowed grantees to use federal capital assistance to purchase spare parts for transit vehicles if the cost of any such part was at least 1/2 of 1% of the cost of the vehicle.  In the past, the "cost of the vehicle" was interpreted to be an equivalent new vehicle.  Effective this year, grantees may use the average depreciated value of the entire fleet to determine the threshold, a change  that effectively reduces the cost of spare parts eligible for federal capital assistance from something in excess  of $1,000 to something lessthan $500 in most cases.     Third party procurement:   an internal FTA task force completed work and presented the Administrator with a  series of recommendations for streamlining and reforming the requirements the agency imposes on its grantees for "third party" contracts that involve federal funds.  A new formal guidance document, Circular 4220.1C, has been  issued.  The circular encourages grantees to rely more on self-certifications, rather than on time-consuming reviews by the FTA.  The new circular also gives grantees new flexibility in adding options to primary contracts, in the use of progress payments (and advanced payments) to vendors, and in the way of requiring vendors to post performance bonds.     Drug and alcohol testing for volunteer drivers:   the FTA issued a "final rule" in August 1995 that exempts certain volunteers who drive vans and other small transit vehicles  from drug and alcohol testing requirements.     New standardized grant assistance contract:   a new basic grant contract will be used beginning October 1, 1995. This new instrument includes terminology that has been updated and revised to reflect recent statutory changes.  The new contract was also designed to be fully compatible with the FTA's electronic grant-making initiative, noted above.         "There is very little that can be called dramatic or glitzy about any of these improvements," Administrator Linton said.  "Some of them are so technical and detailed that only a relatively few people at even the largest transit agencies will have any appreciation of the substantial benefits they represent.  The larger point, though," Linton continued, "is that taken as a whole they clearly demonstrate a strong commitment to making the federal mass transit assistance program serve the needs of its real customers."      POLICY AND PROGRAM EMPHASIS AREAS     Something that ties together a number of innovations and improvements that have recently taken place at the FTA is a program emphasis called  Livable Communities.   "Our Livable Communities initiative is an effort to emphasize the human dimension in transportation," Administrator Linton said.     The assumption behind the Livable Communities initiative is this:  Mass transit facilities have to be tailored to serve more than the transportation needs of their customers, they also have to serve their community needs and their human needs.  As Administrator Linton noted in last year's Report to Our Customers: "Just as transit vehicles have evolved over the years to provide the kind of comfort and convenience customers expect, so must transit facilities evolve to serve the expectations of their communities.  You wouldn't expect to find a transit bus today that isn't heated in the winter and air conditioned in the summer.  Why does it seem so strange, then, when we talk about including day care centers in subway stations, or making sure there are grocery stores adjacent to bus terminals?"     That was Administrator Linton speaking a year ago.  Now, twelve months later and with the FTA's Livable Communities initiative having gained stature and maturity, it no longer seems strange to talk about day care centers in subway stations and convenience stores in bus terminals.       Since last year, 12 separate grants have been awarded under  the Livable Communities initiative; they are displayed in the following table.  But the Livable Communities idea is far more pervasive than simply these 12 individual grants.  Concepts embodied in the Livable Communities effort are interwoven in virtually all the full funding grant agreements that were negotiated over the past year.  Making our communities more livable is a primary tenet of the FTA's Strategic Plan; it will continue to enliven the entire grant assistance program in the years ahead and give it new direction and new purpose.                                                                    Grants Made Under the Livable Communities Initiative    city  project total cost      New York subway station enhancement; Lexington Av. & E.110 St.  $2.8 million     Chester, PA commuter rail station enhancement; community service, safety & access $7.5 million    Baltimore subway station enhancement; day care center, police station & improved access $1.9 million                     Atlanta walkways--transit stations to campus; improved access & safety   $4.0 million            Louisville neighborhood travel center; 'reverse-commute' terminal $3.0 million                     Columbus, OH transit center  in new "planned community"  $10.0 million                    E.Cleveland Head-start facility adjacent to Windermere rapid transit station  $6.0 million    Chicago elevated station enhancement;  improved access & safety $3.4 million Corpus Christi  enhanced access to bus transfer center  $2.1 million    St. Louis  day care center, police substation at Wellston light rail station $1 million    Tucson improved passenger amenities along two-mile transit corridor  $1.3 million    Clackamas County, OR transit plaza $2.0 million            Another policy and program emphasis area over the past year has involved the  innovative financing of mass transit investment projects.       A call was issued (via  Federal Register  announcement) to solicit innovative funding projects.  FTA assistance might involve financial or technical help in developing a financing plan for the proposed project, direct financial assistance for the project itself, or administrative relief from certain customary FTA project requirements.   Following the publication of this call, 69 applications were received:  direct financial assistance grants were awarded to eight of these, and regulatory flexibility will be provided in eight additional cases.  An FTA-retained contractor with expertise in municipal financing, bond issuance and other financial  techniques is also available to provide technical assistance to additional applicants.   The FTA also published an  Innovative Financing Handbook  outlining several of the more innovative or complex techniques that grantees may use to leverage additional capital investment from public and private sources.   Like the Livable Communities initiative, the use of innovative financing mechanisms can be expected to play a larger role within the FTA program in the years ahead.    DEFENSE CONVERSION       Through its research arm--renamed the Office of Research, Demonstration and Innovation in the recent reorganization--the FTA has become a very important player in the overall national effort to find new  domestic activities  for the  enormous industrial potential that was developed  in our country  during the cold war . This, of course, is in addition to on-going activities in traditional areas of transit research.        On Labor Day, President Clinton announced a grant of $2.5 million to help establish a production line for electric-powered vehicles at a former naval air station.  On September 18, 1995 a consortium of over 140 public and private organizations known as CALSTART rolled out an advanced 35-foot electric bus that had been built with FTA funds; it will now undergo perational testing in Santa Barbara, CA.  A unit of the Department of Defense called the Advanced Research Projects Agency (ARPA) has supplied the FTA with over $10 million to help develop a new generation of transit buses that will be powered by fuel cells, and almost $20 million to design a new automatic train control system for rail rapid transit.  To allow the transit industry to take maximum advantage of the informational capabilities represented by Geographic Information Systems (GIS) technology, the FTA is arranging for  every bus route in the country  to be individually scanned into a GIS data base maintained at the John Joseph        Moakley Center at Bridgewater State College in Massachusetts.          Several publications are available that supply further information about these and other FTA's research activities;  Transit Planning and Research Reports; an Annotated Bibliography  [August 1995], and  Transit Planning and Research Programs; Fiscal Year 1994 Project Directory  [March 1995].  For copies contact the FTA's Office of Research Management; 202-366-3765 (fax) or 202-366-0201 (telephone).    OTHER FTA ACCOMPLISHMENTS     A number of additional FTA accomplishments from the past year deserve mention in this Report to Our Customers.    The 1996 Olympics:   last year's Report to Our Customers told of the FTA's assuming a leadership role in ensuring that the upcoming Olympic Games in Atlanta in the summer of        1996 will give mass transit an opportunity to showcase its ability to move people in and out of a concentrated area. Over the past year, commitments have been received from over two dozen U.S. transit systems to lease up to 2,100 new (or almost new) transit buses to Atlanta for the duration of the Olympics, and a grant for $14 million was awarded by the FTA to fund expenses associated with moving  this fleet to and from Atlanta.  In addition, the FTA has funded an extensive deployment of new passenger information        technology in Atlanta that will have applicability during the Olympics, but will remain in place afterward as               a permanent enhancement of the area's mass transportation system.  Art in Transit:   in addition to publishing a revised              circular, No. 9400.1A, that updates policy on when and how        artistic works may be included in federally-funded mass           transit projects, the FTA also began to promote the notion        that artistic treatment should be included in mass transit        vehicles and facilities.  Circular No. 9400.1A was                published in the form of an attractive 4-color brochure           that included ample illustrations of recent artistic work  at mass transit projects.  Bus Summit Conference:   in an effort to learn what are the        distinctive problems being faced by U.S. manufacturers of        mass transit buses, on September 22, 1995 the FTA held an        unprecedented "summit conference" of such manufacturers in        Washington.  Feed-back received at the meeting will assist        the FTA in crafting new policies and procedures in the        months ahead.   Memorandum of Understanding with South Africa:   in March,         Administrator Linton was one of the formal signatories, on        behalf of the United States Government, on a formal        Memorandum of Understanding with the Republic of South        Africa that will see technology sharing and information        exchange between the two countries on matters associated        with transportation.                IVHS Becomes ITS:   to emphasize its multi-modal character,        a major Department of Transportation research initiative          that was initially called IVHS--Intelligent Vehicle    Highway Systems --has been formally and officially renamed         ITS--Intelligent Transportation Systems.  Over the past           year, a "coordinated system architecture" for public              transportation vehicles was completed, thus ensuring full         participation by mass transportation in the overall ITS           initiative.    Americans With Disabilities Act:   during the year, the FTA         received and reviewed 530 paratransit plan updates,               conducted four additional ADA training sessions (bringing         the total to 21), negotiated 23 voluntary compliance              agreements with rail transit systems concerning timetables         for making key stations accessible, and through Project           ACTION, invited experts from the transit industry and the         disabled community to Washington in July 1995 for a two-        day conference on paratransit issues.    Passenger Security Conferences :  a series of conferences          were held to help focus attention on issues associated with        the personal security of passengers who ride mass transit         systems.     SUMMARY    Over the summer of 1995, issues associated with the FTA's  budget for FY 1996 generated a good deal of serious and oftentimes intense debate over what the federal role should be in mass  transit.   All this debate was just a warm-up,  however, for the  much more fundamental discussions that will necessarily take place  in the months ahead as we move closer to the time when  ISTEA must be re-authorized.   What should happen to federal transit operating subsidies?  How far can we extend the concepts of flexible funding that were begun in ISTEA?  Should other forms of surface  transportation besides highways and mass transit be made eligible for funding from existing trust funds?  What is the proper mix  between formula allocations and discretionary programs?   These are fundamental questions.  Furthermore, they are  questions that will necessarily have to be addressed within a  larger framework of constrained resources at all levels and  rapidly changing expectations about what the federal government  should be doing across a very broad spectrum of domestic activity.         The time between this APTA annual meeting in the fall of 1995 and next year's meeting in 1996 when the FTA will again issue a  Report to Our Customers promises to be very interesting.              http://www.fta.dot.gov/library/intro/cust/rep2cust.html

Regional Transit Planning   Summary  March 1992      The Twin Cities metropolitan area has a complex, multi-tiered structure for planning and implementing public transit improvements.  Agencies involved include the Metropolitan Council, the Regional Transit Board (RTB), "opt-out" communities, and the Metropolitan Transit Commission (MTC) and other transit operators.  In addition, the area's seven counties are responsible for acquiring right-of-way and planning for new light rail transit lines, and the Minnesota Department of Transportation (Mn/DOT) is involved in planning and constructing highway improvements which may include transit components.   In spite of this level of agency involvement, there have been continuing concerns about transit performance and the adequacy of transit planning.  During the 1980s, the Twin Cities area has experienced a substantial decline in bus ridership, growing highway congestion, and only limited suburban transit expansions outside of opt-out communities.  In addition, the area has been split by disagreement over the desirability of implementing light rail transit.   This report examines transit planning in the Twin Cities area and addresses the following questions:   * What progress has the Regional Transit Board made in planning for and implementing cost-effective transit service improvements, as well as providing oversight of existing transit operations?   * Has the Metropolitan Council provided adequate long-range planning and policy direction for transit and highway improvements?   * Has the Minnesota Department of Transportation appropriately integrated transit into its highway planning and construction activities?   * Has transit planning become too fragmented and are structural changes needed to improve planning?   * What are the strengths and weaknesses of the Metropolitan Council's new Regional Transit Facilities Plan and the Regional Transit Board's new Vision for Transit?   In general, we found a planning process which has been dominated in recent years by light rail transit to the exclusion of other transit options such as improved bus service and high-occupancy vehicle (HOV) lanes.  In addition, the growing costs of Metro Mobility have made it difficult for the Regional Transit Board to expand suburban bus service.   Over the last year, however, the Metropolitan Council has taken steps to reorient the planning process and more vigorously oversee the work of the Regional Transit Board.  The Council's new facilities plan and the RTB's new transit vision are steps in the right direction, although many of their details will need to be worked out in the next few years.    Regional Transit Board   In 1984, the Legislature created the Regional Transit Board to do short- and mid-range transit planning, contract for transit services, and review and approve transit budgets.  The Legislature wanted the RTB to control rising transit costs, respond to growing suburban transit needs, improve oversight of the Metropolitan Transit Commission (MTC), and more closely integrate transit into the region's highway planning.  In a 1988 evaluation, we concluded that RTB had not yet proven to be an effective problem solver.  Now, four years later, we conclude that:   * Although creation of the Regional Transit Board was a good idea, the Board's progress has not lived up to expectations in several key areas.   * Progress in some key areas has been slow and problems remain, but there have been some encouraging signs recently.  * The major problems with RTB's past performance are:   * There has been little progress in responding to growing suburban transit needs outside of opt-out communities.   * RTB has been slow to provide adequate oversight of the Metropolitan Transit Commission despite substantial declines in regular route ridership.   * RTB still does not have an adequate policy on competitive bidding of bus service and has allowed MTC to provide a significant amount of peak-hour express service outside MTC's exclusive service area despite significant questions regarding MTC's relative efficiency in providing that service.   * RTB has not provided needed leadership from a regional perspective on light rail transit, and has focused too much on expensive transit options and too little on relatively inexpensive solutions.   In part, these problems have resulted from factors external to RTB.  For example, state funding for transit has been relatively constant in recent years while Metro Mobility costs have grown significantly.  The increase in costs has limited RTB's ability to fund service improvements for suburban areas and in the existing regular route system.  Some of the increase in Metro Mobility costs is the direct result of RTB's decisions to expand and improve service.  However, RTB did not anticipate much of the growth in ridership and costs.  In addition, the planning process has been dominated by light rail transit (LRT) in recent years.  Considerable staff and board time devoted to LRT has taken time and attention away from other issues.   However, factors within RTB's control have been at work as well.  These include: 1) the board's promotion of LRT without adequate examination of the alternatives, 2) the board's attitude toward contracting transit services, 3) continuing internal tension due to the agency having both an executive director and a full-time chair, and 4) the board's unwillingness to control Metro Mobility costs, which led to an expenditure cap being imposed by the 1991 Legislature.   On the positive side, we found that:   * RTB recently adopted new plans which attempt to improve suburban transit service and control Metro Mobility expenditures.   * RTB is developing five transit hubs in suburban locations and has experimented with four new suburban services which are either circulators or general purpose dial-a-rides.   * Despite turnover, RTB has a strong staff which has laid a good foundation for the future with the work it has done on various planning projects and in contract management.   * Since mid-1991, the Board has shown more interest in overseeing MTC as well as assisting it in improving ridership and efficiency.   RTB recently completed a marketing study to determine reasons for the loss in MTC ridership and identify marketing strategies to address that concern.  In addition, RTB's budget for 1992 includes funds to conduct management audits of MTC and funds for MTC to perform a comprehensive operations analysis of MTC routes.    Metropolitan Council   The Metropolitan Council is responsible for long-range planning and policy making for both transit and highways in the Twin Cities area and for overseeing the work of the Regional Transit Board.  In our 1988 evaluation, we were critical of the Metropolitan Council's relatively weak oversight of RTB and lack of adequate policy direction for transit and highways.    Since 1988, with adoption of a new transportation policy plan, the Council's planning work and policy direction gradually improved and, in the last year, improved dramatically.  We found that:   * Until last year, the Metropolitan Council did not provide adequate oversight of the Regional Transit Board.   * Until this year, the Metropolitan Council did not provide sufficient leadership in formulating a long-range vision for transit in the region.   These recent improvements in Council oversight and leadership have come about in two ways:   * The Metropolitan Council and its staff provided significant oversight of RTB through the Council's review of the RTB's Five Year Plan in May 1991.   * The Metropolitan Council and its staff have provided significant leadership for future transit and highway improvements with the recent adoption of its Regional Transit Facilities Plan.   The plan is significant in that it recommends an even-handed approach to transit planning.  While LRT has dominated planning in recent years, the Council's plan calls for service improvements, minor capital improvements, and major capital projects according to their effectiveness in solving transit and highway problems in various parts of the region.   The plan's specific recommendations for transit improvements should not, however, be viewed as definitive.  In developing the plan, staff have not been able to analyze in detail all of the transit options in each highway corridor.  For example, staff did not have time to fully analyze the benefits and costs of LRT compared to bus and other options in the Central Corridor between St. Paul and Minneapolis.  However, the plan recommends a process -- an alternatives analysis -- through which this important consideration will be examined.    Minnesota Department of Transportation   The Minnesota Department of Transportation (Mn/DOT) plays an indirect, but important, role in transit planning.  Many transit services and car pools utilize the highways which Mn/DOT is responsible for planning and constructing.  As a result, Mn/DOT's cooperation with transit planning agencies is vital in helping them achieve their goals.   We found that:   * Mn/DOT has been receptive to transit issues and has incorporated various transit options into its highway plans.   Mn/DOT has worked with the Metropolitan Council in providing bus and car pool bypass ramps at freeway exits as called for in the Council's 1988 Transportation Policy Plan.  Mn/DOT is currently working with MTC on MTC's "Team Transit" project to provide lane and ramp improvements which could help buses reduce their travel time and potentially increase their ridership.  Finally, Mn/DOT has constructed high-occupancy vehicle lanes, park-and-ride lots, and transit stations in the I-394 corridor west of downtown Minneapolis and is analyzing HOV lanes, as well as light rail transit, in its planning process for improvements to I-35W from downtown Minneapolis south to the Minnesota River.    Recommendations    Legislature   We have five types of legislative recommendations, which address: 1) internal RTB structural problems, 2) LRT funding and governance, 3) financial disincentives for automobile use, 4) funding for transit improvements, and 5) the need for oversight of RTB.  Regarding RTB's internal structure, we recommend that:   * The Legislature should either make the position of RTB chair a part-time one or permit the chair to select the executive director with the board's approval.   Since its inception, there has been internal tension at RTB because the agency essentially has two heads: an executive director and a full-time chair.  This situation is not a viable one for an agency as small as RTB.  It will continue to struggle to meet expectations unless it goes forward under strong and consistent leadership.   Second, we recommend that:   * The Legislature should not fund construction of LRT in the Central Corridor until a satisfactory alternatives analysis has been prepared.   * The Legislature should change the governance structure for light rail transit planning to provide for more regional control of the process while continuing to involve county railroad authorities in a meaningful way.   The Metropolitan Council's facilities plan shows that, within the next 20 years, only two LRT lines -- the Central Corridor and the I-35W South lines -- have the potential to be cost-effective under reasonable assumptions.  Recent studies show that these two lines have a combined projected cost of just under $4.00 per rider -- the maximum permitted by Metropolitan Council policy in order for a line to be considered for implementation before the year 2010.  Furthermore, it has yet to be determined how the benefits and costs of a Central Corridor LRT line -- the Council's highest LRT priority -- compare to those for all-bus and other alternatives.  As a result, it is important that an alternatives analysis be conducted before more design work continues or construction work begins.  An alternatives analysis will also improve the region's chances of maximizing the amount of federal "new start" money which can be received and used to reduce the region's costs of building the line.   The current governance structure for light rail transit planning is dominated by the region's counties and their rail authorities.  Their only transit mission is to plan for light rail transit.  Considering the new cost per rider estimates for LRT, the need for objective analysis of alternatives, and the need to use regional or state funding to implement LRT -- there is a need to reorient the governance structure to ensure that regional goals are met and that spending on additional lines is not continued.  We are generally supportive of the Metropolitan Council's proposed governance structure.  That proposal would place RTB in charge of the alternatives analysis, Mn/DOT in charge of design and construction, and MTC in charge of operations.  However, given the counties' leadership on LRT issues, the Legislature should consider ways in which the counties can be given a meaningful role in the design and construction of LRT, while assuring regional control over important decisions.   We also recommend that:   * The Legislature should examine options for increasing automobile user costs to better reflect the costs to the region of automobile travel.   A modest increase in automobile user costs through additional gasoline taxes or other taxes or fees may help to limit future growth in automobile travel and would better reflect some of the regional costs of automobile use.  It would also make sense to use a portion of any tax or fee increase to help fund transit improvements or relieve some of the current burden on property taxes.  However, Constitutional limitations and budgetary constraints will affect the options available to the Legislature.   If transit programs are allotted funds from a new funding source, it is essential that the Legislature retain control over transit funding and not provide transit agencies with an unlimited source of dedicated funding.  Many of the recommendations in the Council's new facilities plan and RTB's new vision are conceptual and lack ridership estimates and other details which would help in determining their cost-effectiveness.  Legislative oversight of these agencies' recommendations is needed before transit funding is substantially increased.  The Legislature should take an incremental approach and fund some improvements while requiring the agencies to report back on their progress in developing more detailed plans and ridership estimates.  We recommend that:   * The Legislature should be generally supportive of the concepts contained in the Metropolitan Council's facilities plan.   * However, the Legislature should require RTB and the Council to provide information on the potential cost-effectiveness of the recommended service improvements and transit hub projects.   We also recommend that the Legislature strengthen oversight of RTB in the following ways:   * The Legislature should require RTB to prepare an annual performance report for existing transit services and submit the report to the Metropolitan Council for its review and comment.   * The Legislature should require RTB to report at least annually on its progress in implementing its five-year plan and submit the report to the Metropolitan Council for its review and comment.   * The Legislature should give the Metropolitan Council authority to review and approve RTB's annual capital budget and review and comment on RTB's annual operating budget.    Metropolitan Council   We recommend that:   * The Metropolitan Council continue the strong oversight and leadership it has shown over the last year.   In addition, even without specific legislative authorization, we recommend that:   * The Metropolitan Council should consider requiring RTB to prepare: 1) an annual transit performance report, 2) an annual progress report on plan implementation, and 3) cost per rider estimates for the new services and other mass transit improvements recommended in the Council's new plan and RTB's new vision.   Also, in formulating regional policy on highway and transit development, the Council should consider the extent to which automobile users are not directly paying the full costs of automobile use.  We recommend that the Metropolitan Council: 1) determine the extent to which automobile users do not directly pay for the costs imposed on the region from automobile use, 2) examine the potential effect on automobile and transit use from raising automobile ownership and operation costs through additional taxes or other methods, and 3) study the impact which such action might have on future development patterns.    Regional Transit Board   The Regional Transit Board has made only slow progress in achieving the goals envisioned when it was established.  Improvement has been made since mid-1991, but it remains to be seen whether such improvement will be sustained.  The RTB's Vision for Transit has conceptual appeal, but lacks important details.  It is unclear at this point how much of the vision should be implemented.  It is also unclear how the results of needs assessments and MTC's comprehensive operations analysis will affect the vision.   Despite reservations, we believe RTB should continue to exist in its current form.  The separation of planning and operations has had some desirable effects and remains a good concept.  However, RTB needs to continue the progress of the last eight months and demonstrate to the Legislature that RTB can be an effective problem solver.  RTB can best develop this trust by being a fair and objective planning agency.  Advocacy on behalf of transit is best based on sound and thoughtful analysis. Specifically, we recommend that:   * RTB should adopt a competitive bidding policy which adequately addresses the costing method MTC should use when bidding to provide transit services outside its exclusive service area.   * RTB should undertake the proposed management audits of MTC and review the comprehensive operations analysis of MTC when completed.  RTB should ultimately identify any resources which can be freed up to provide needed service improvements.   * RTB should examine the need for and potential cost-effectiveness of the service improvements and hubs recommended in the Metropolitan Council's facilities plan.  Not all of the hubs and accompanying circulator and express routes may be cost-effective.   * RTB should prepare an annual performance report which provides performance statistics for each route and type of service funded by RTB.   * RTB should continue its recent efforts to work cooperatively with the opt-out providers and assist them in competitively bidding out transit services when their current contracts end.   * RTB should work with MTC to strengthen the region's efforts to encourage ridesharing or consider moving Minnesota Rideshare to the Minnesota Department of Transportation. Introduction and Executive Summary   Introduction and Executive Summary To meet the increasing demand for sound, safe and secure transportation, many in the transportation community believe that the next transportation authorization must build upon the successes of previous years. After all, transportation is vital to the state and national economy, as well as our way of life. Rural and urban interests alike equally depend on quality transportation to remain viable and competitive in a changing national and global economy. In 1998, Congress enacted the six-year Transportation Equity Act for the 21st Century (TEA-21). TEA- 21 increased the federal investment in highways and transit 40 percent above the previous six-year transportation act, titled the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act (ISTEA). This increase in federal assistance has enabled states, cities and counties to accelerate repairs to highways and to increase capacity. New and expanded transit services, including fleet modernization, have helped transit ridership to reach record levels. The intent of the reauthorization effort is to build upon the successes of ISTEA and TEA-21 by continuing to focus on maintaining and improving system condition and performance; project and process streamlining; minimizing ineffective policy requirements; and identifying a menu of options that Congress may use to increase the federal financial commitment to the nation's highway and transit systems. As impressive as the 40 percent increase in funding was from ISTEA to TEA-21, the needs of our growing economy, substantial increase in usage by the public and the deterioration of an aged system will require even more investments in the transportation system. The Federal Highway Administration's Condition and Performance Report has identified a need for an annual investment of $92 billion to maintain the national system and an annual investment of $125 billion to improve and expand the system. The national repair backlog for highways and bridges is estimated at $254 billion. To put this in perspective, the total federal highway program authorized in TEA-21 for fiscal year 2003 is approximately $28 billion. Although Minnesota's transportation infrastructure and transit system investments have exceeded that of many other states, Minnesota's transportation reauthorization issues are the same: a multi-year state and federal investment strategy designed to maintain and expand Minnesota's current system. Mn/DOT has worked with different customer, stakeholder and government groups to develop ten positions that offer policy recommendations on how to maximize the benefit to Minnesota and other states afforded by the reauthorization of TEA-21.  The TEA-21 reauthorization positions are organized in the following areas:  Financial Issues  Reviewing improvements in programs and systems needed to address highway fatalities  Security Issues  Promoting a focused approach to transportation infrastructure and systems security enhancements  Safety Issues  Recommending the further implementation of safety improvement strategies to serve one of Minnesota's top transportation priorities  Freight Transportation Issues Presenting multi-modal transportation integration proposals  Transit Issues  Proposing policy adjustments and examining funding needs  Statewide and Metropolitan Planning Programs  Streamlining and coordinating planning processes  Interjurisdictional and Institutional Issues Environmental Stewardship and Streamlining Issues  Enabling governments to work together better  Enhancing the commitment to environmental stewardship and streamlining as Mn/DOT pursues the goal of delivering faster, better transportation projects  Research Issues  Providing information to develop better, safer transportation programs  Operations/Intelligent Transportation Systems Issues  Developing and deploying technologies and techniques to make transportation systems operate more efficiently  2   Financial Issues "The two financial focal areas for reauthorization are increasing levels of funding and program policy improvements." A safe and efficient transportation system is key to economic health and personal mobility. Having the financial resources necessary to maintain adequate highway and system performance is a never-ending challenge. Current estimates for the funding necessary to maintain the existing system are more than triple current federal program levels. Many funding components of TEA-21 have worked well and need to be continued. Congress should: s s s s s Maintain the TEA-21 program structure, increase flexibility and expand program eligibility to address priority needs rather than establish new set-asides and sub-allocations. Preserve TEA-21's federal highway funding guarantees and budgetary firewalls. Refine the Revenue Aligned Budget Authority (RABA) to ensure that all funds collected for the Highway Trust Fund are returned to the states. Ensure no new funding sanctions or incentive programs are established. Maintain and enhance innovative project financing techniques including the expansion of State Infrastructure Bank (SIB) eligibility to all states and lowering the Transportation Infrastructure Financing Innovation Act (TIFIA) minimum loan amount. Address federal gasohol revenue issues that penalizes some states for its usage. Expand and authorize further development of alternative funding programs such as mileagebased user fees and value pricing as revenue sources for the Highway Trust Fund. Address the growing backlog of highway and transit program needs by increasing the federal program funding to $41 billion a year and at least $10 billion per year for transit programs by FFY2009.  s s s  To achieve this, Congress may utilize a mix of the following options: o o o o Draw down Highway Trust Fund reserves; Capture the interest on the HTF reserves; Capture gasohol tax revenues currently attributed to the general fund; and Expand innovative financing options and explore new funding mechanisms.  Security Issues "All levels of government have responsibility to minimize the vulnerability of critical infrastructure assets and to prepare for transportation's role in emergency response and recovery." The heightened threat of terrorism has introduced new security imperatives to the nation's highway and transit programs. While surface transportation infrastructure is robust and redundant, the consequences of a large-scale attack could be significant. Congress should: s s s Authorize a moderate increase and broaden eligibility in existing federal-aid highway programs to support security activities. Direct federal agencies to provide expedited environmental and planning processes for security-related projects. Direct the Federal Highway Administration to establish federal vulnerability assessment guidelines; and create a new program to protect critical, security-related infrastructure, facilities and equipment. Increase federal-aid highway funding for security, hazardous materials and safety-related incident response and management, and allow state DOTs to have access to general funds to develop improved nationally standard, inter-operable and hardened communications system.  s  3   Safety Issues Safety is and will remain a priority for Minnesota. The next federal transportation bill should include enhanced safety planning, flexible funding for infrastructure improvements and support for application of effective low-cost safety improvement strategies. Congress should: s Increase the highway safety program by $1 billion per year specifically to implement the state's comprehensive highway safety plan, with increased flexibility to transfer funds between sub-categories. Consolidate several safety grant programs into a single, flexible Section 402 highway safety program that would be goal-oriented and risk-based. Provide additional funding from other sources than the Highway Trust Fund for the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration's Safety Assistance Program. Maintain a safety monitoring program for Mexican motor carriers and all new entrant American and Canadian-based carriers.  "The increase in motor carrier and commercial vehicle traffic at the nation's borders since the passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement has increased concerns about safety."  s s s  Freight Transportation Issues During the past two decades, freight transportation by all modes has experienced tremendous growth. These increases have taxed the capacity of our ports, rail lines, highways and airports. Without increased investment in infrastructure, innovative financing, flexible funding and improved operational efficiency, the competitive advantage Minnesota and the nation enjoy in global markets will erode. Congress should: s s s Support the use of existing innovative financing tools and new financing mechanisms for investments in freight transportation infrastructure. Ensure that federal-aid highway programs are flexible enough to allow for planning, engineering and construction of intermodal connectors. Enact an increase in the Federal Highway Administration's research and technology program to allow for a greater emphasis on freight transportation research and create a Freight Transportation Cooperative Research program. Provide up to $10 million annually to support U.S.DOT and state DOT efforts to implement a training and capacity-building program. Establish a national Freight Advisory Group as the mechanism for the freight industry and public sector to communicate with "one voice" to the U.S.DOT freight transportation issues. The Minnesota Freight Advisory Committee may serve as a model to receive input from the freight community to advance freight issues.  "It is estimated that even modest economic growth will double the volume of export/import tonnage and increase domestic tonnage by 70 percent in the next twenty years, which will tax the capacity of our ports, rail lines, highways, and airports."  s s  4   Transit Issues "Transit is one of several options to reduce highway congestion and improving air quality." As with ISTEA and TEA-21, the upcoming reauthorization should focus on a balanced intermodal transportation system for the nation. Transit provides mobility, access to jobs, shopping, health care and many other services to Minnesotans. Transit is one of several options to reduce highway congestion and improve air quality. Congress should: s s s s s s Increase transit program funding up to $10 billion per year by FFY 2009, while: Maintaining transit funding guarantees established in TEA-21; Maintaining the 80/20 match requirements for transit projects; Continue to supplement Highway Trust Fund transit programs with general funds; and Continue transit funding flexibility and eligibility for innovative financing programs, such as TIFIA and SIBs. Allow for larger transit systems to self-certify compliance with the Federal Transit Administration's incidental charter service rules and allow the state DOT to certify for other transit agencies. Give the state more flexibility to determine the percentage of federal transit funds allocated to intercity bus service and allow the states to submit annual Section 5311 applications based on total needs of the state, including needs-based percentage of intercity bus services. Amend the Federal Transit Administration's "Buy American" provisions to allow bus and equipment manufacturers to self-certify that they are in compliance. Direct the Federal Transit Administration and the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration to consolidate drug and alcohol testing regulations to simplify the process and reduce the cost of compliance for small urban and rural transit operators.  s  s s  Statewide and Metropolitan Planning Issues "Many in the transportation community consider Minnesota a model for cooperative, progressive planning and financial decision making with regional and local governments." Building upon the success of ISTEA, the current framework for statewide and metropolitan transportation planning was established in TEA-21. This framework reflects significant changes in the transportation planning process that have strengthened stakeholder and public involvement, established multi-modal planning processes, and are sensitive to a multitude of factors from environmental, economic development and improved access to transportation facilities and services. Congress should: s s Change the update cycle requirements for metropolitan long range plans from three years to five years Increase the flexibility related to financial constraints in State and Metropolitan Transportation Plans and Transportation Improvement Plans(TIPs). Congress should permit projects for which discretionary funding is being sought to be included in financially constrained TIPs. This should only be allowed when both anticipated revenues and the costs are included in a way that they can be identified separately from the rest of the TIP. Continue to provide flexibility to states as to the content of long-range plans, performance measures and planning horizons, so long as a minimum 20-year horizon is maintained. Recognize the state DOT and Metropolitan Planning Organizations legitimate role in decision-making on connections to the national highway system or other highway facilities adjacent to ports, airports and freight terminals.  s s  5   Interjurisdictional and Institutional Issues States provide a central role in the development of the surface transportation system, even as other jurisdictions, institutions, local governments, metropolitan planning organizations, tribal governments and federal agencies themselves have come to play important parts. The current decision-making structure that recognizes the state's leadership in the development of transportation plans, programs and projects is essential in delivering a comprehensive transportation system in Minnesota. TEA-21 recognizes that the federal highway program is a federally assisted state program and Congress should maintain and affirm the state's leadership role and authority in reauthorization. Congress should: s Continue TEA-21's decision-making processes and procedures for transportation planning, programming and project selection. This involves retaining the balance of decision-making between the states and MPOs, and the states and rural officials. In addition, it is essential to retain the current definitions of planning as "consultation, cooperation and coordination." Protect state discretion, flexibility, innovation and accountability in the statewide planning process while affirming the importance of the federal-aid highway program's transportation mission, specifically: o o o o o Provide maximum flexibility to the states to apply the statewide planning provisions and interact with MPOs and extra-MPO organizations. Pursue creative solutions while honoring and striving to achieve the intent of the federal legislation. Retain the statutory provisions that protect state discretion and ensure state level flexibility, innovation and accountability. Congress should confirm in statute the requirement for state concurrence in the planning and selection of public lands highway projects, including forest highways. Congress should ensure that federal statutes continue to defer to state and local governments on whether and how to consider land use in the course of transportation planning. Congress should ensure that federal statutes support balanced transportation investment strategies that are based on statewide and metropolitan planning processes. Congress should support the concept that preservation of the existing system involves more than pavement preservation, including enhancing safety and modernizing highways and transit to bring them up to current design standards.  "TEA-21 recognizes that the federal highway program is a "federally assisted state program" and it is important that Congress maintain and reaffirm the state's leadership role and authority in reauthorization."  s  o  s  Congress should reaffirm the primary transportation mission of the federal highway program, while acknowledging support for multiple policy goals. Congress should oppose revisions to federal law that impose new cost components that detract from the primary transportation mission. TEA-21 Reauthorization: A Detailed Review of Mn/DOT's Policy Positions  Financial Issues "Current estimates for the funding necessary to maintain the existing system are more than triple current federal program levels."  Overview A safe and efficient transportation system is key to the economy and to personal mobility. ISTEA and TEA-21 have had enormous impact on the nation's transportation system. Together they dramatically increased investment in roads and bridges, spurred growth in public transportation and helped to create a more efficient and interconnected transportation system. Failure to continue the gains made in the past decade will impact our global competitiveness, hinder access to jobs and services and will increase congestion and compromise highway safety. Having the financial resources necessary to maintain adequate highway condition and system performance is a never-ending challenge. Current estimates for the funding necessary to maintain the existing system are more than triple current federal program levels. State resources are equally inadequate. Many funding components of TEA-21 have worked well and need to be continued. To address the growing disparity between need and resources in the next federal transportation legislation, a variety of other financial options need to be either implemented or expanded. Similarly, funding generated by transportation that is not attributed to transportation programs needs to be captured into the Highway Trust Fund. In general, Mn/DOT's position on financial issues related to the federal transportation program mirrors that of other state DOTs and the transportation industry. Most would agree that TEA21 is working well but several policy adjustments are necessary. The two financial focal areas for reauthorization are increasing levels of funding and program policy improvements. Additional federal funding is essential to meet increasing program needs.  With that in mind, the following is a summary of financial issues that need to be addressed in the next authorization.  Policy principles Maintain funding guarantees and firewalls - To ensure that domestic discretionary spending caps do not prevent the use of all available revenues, a firewall provision was inserted in the Budget Enforcement Act to increase or decrease highway spending each year consistent with Highway Trust Funds receipts. Congress should preserve TEA-21's highway funding guarantees and firewalls. RABA - In TEA-21, Congress intended for all revenues in the Highway Account of the Highway Trust Fund to be used solely for the federal highway program. To ensure full utilization of actual receipts in the HTF, the law created a new mechanism to annually adjust the original TEA-21 authorizations to reflect updated revenue estimates. Under the Revenue Aligned Budget Authority (RABA), budget authority and obligation levels are increased or decreased to reflect changes in revenues. RABA adjustments are based on two calculations: a "look back" at actual receipts in the Highway Trust Fund (FFY 2003 is based on FFY 2001 receipts) and a "look forward" at projected anticipated receipts. The first four years of TEA-21 reflected a robust economy and increases in vehicle miles traveled and commercial vehicle sales, which contribute to HTF balances. This resulted in "positive" RABA and additional revenues for federal transportation programs. Minnesota has received $115 million in additional funding through the RABA provisions through FFY 2002. However, recent U.S. Treasury collections and revenue projections  "Funding generated by transportation that is not attributed to transportation programs needs to be captured into the Highway Trust Fund."  9   could result in a downward or "negative" RABA adjustment of $5 billion in FFY'03. In reauthorizing TEA-21, Congress should modify the RABA mechanism to avoid severe swings in revenue projections while preserving the principle of expending all funds available in the Highway Trust Fund. A refined RABA mechanism, coupled with guarantees and firewalls, is necessary to ensure that all receipts to the HTF are available for the program, excluding only what is necessary to maintain a prudent cash balance required by Congress. Basic program structure - TEA-21 programs that include the Interstate Maintenance, Bridge, National Highway System, Surface Transportation, and Congestion Mitigation/Air Quality Programs distributed by formula to the states are working well and should be retained. Increased flexibility - Greater flexibility and expanded program eligibility should be used to address priority needs, rather than establish new set-asides and suballocations. Program flexibility will allow states to tailor funding to individual state needs and avoid a cookie cutter approach to transportation program delivery. Innovative financing - Congress should maintain and enhance current innovative project financing techniques, including the expansion of State Infrastructure Bank (SIB) eligibility to all states and lowering the Transportation Infrastructure Financing Innovation Act (TIFIA) threshold from $100 million to $50 million. Incentives and sanctions - Congress should not establish any new funding sanctions and incentive programs, as well as convert any existing sanctions to incentive-based criteria. Many sanctioned activities are a direct result of state legislative action/inaction, not  under the control of state DOTs. Sanctioning of funding, particularly in the area of safety programs, works against safety efforts they are intended to support. If a specific program change is necessary, Congress may take action to address its concerns.  Funding issues Under TEA-21, federal transportation funding grew by approximately 40 percent. The transportation industry collectively agrees that a primary focus for reauthorization should be to "grow" the program. For federal fiscal year 2002, the transportation program was $31.8 billion nationally and approximately $408 million for Minnesota. With the current national economic conditions in mind, AASHTO recommends a minimum program size of $34 billion for FFY 2004 with a guaranteed annual increase of 4 percent, resulting in a program of at least $41 billion by FFY2009. For Minnesota, if current TEA-21 funding methods/formulas remain, the state could anticipate approximately $424 million for FFY 2004 and approximately $516 million for FFY2009 in federal funding. Alternative funding - Hybrid electric and other alternative fueled vehicles, such as fuel cell engines, are already entering the market. These and other advances in vehicle engineering offer solutions to the problems associated with fossil fuel consumption. However, they also create a new challenge for state transportation departments throughout the country; as fuel consumption decreases, the revenue stream from motor vehicle fuel taxes will be significantly impacted. Alternatives to the gas tax, such as mileage-based user fees, should be thoroughly explored. Mn/DOT has been leading a 15 state pooled-fund project that is suggesting possible policy options and technology applications to address this problem. A  "Mn/DOT has been leading a 15 state pooledfund project that is suggesting possible policy options and technology applications to address the problems associated with the increase usage of alternative-fueled vehicles."  10   "Minnesota has seen a significant growth in congestion during the past decade and looks to innovative solutions like value pricing to reduce the impact of congestion and to optimize transportation system performance."  national level demonstration of possible technologies should be authorized. Value pricing - The federal value pricing program currently provides grants to qualifying authorities to implement value pricing demonstration projects which use market based principles to manage the system. Minnesota, like many parts of the country, has seen significant growth in congestion during the past decade, with the prospect for more worse conditions in the coming decades. Innovative programs such as value pricing need to be expanded to provide more financial resources to encourage states to better utilize existing investments and to capture revenue for system improvements. AASHTO estimates that travel growth, which is projected at an average of 3 percent per year, will generate approximately $17.6 billion in additional gas tax revenues during the life of the act. Even with the anticipated growth in travel, the federal program will fall short of the funding necessary to achieve the $41 billion program level. Congress will have to implement changes to the current revenue stream for the transportation program. Any combination of the following list of funding options has been identified as possible ways to increase the program size without direct motor fuel tax increases. 1) Drawing down the Highway Trust Fund reserves- The current balance in the HTF is over $20 billion. The transportation industry believes that a minimum Highway Account balance of $7-8 billion is prudent. Even with anticipated decreases in HTF balances for the next few years, due in part to increased TEA21 spending, AASHTO estimates that it is possible to draw down the HTF by a total of $4.4 billion over the six-year reauthorization period while maintaining the mandated minimum HTF balance.  2) Capturing the interest on HTF reserves In writing TEA-21, Congress agreed that the interest on HTF balances would be credited to the general fund in exchange for guaranteed funding and budgetary firewalls. It is estimated that at an assumed rate of 5 percent, the interest would amount to approximately $2.6 billion over the six years of the next act. It appears that many transportation organizations are now pushing for the interest on the HTF balances to be credited to the HTF again. However, the administration has concerns that capturing the interest on the HTF would be an intragovernmental funding transfer that negatively affects on the federal deficit. 3) Gasohol a. Capture gasohol tax revenues currently attributed to the general fund - As part of deficit reduction efforts of the late 1980s, 2.5 cents of the current 13.1 cent per gallon gasohol tax is transferred from the HTF to the General Fund. There have been several recent legislative proposals to redirect the 2.5 cents per gallon of gasohol revenue from the General Fund to the Highway Account of the HTF. The basic principle is that all revenues generated by highway purposes need to be attributed to the HTF Highway Account. (Note: The Mass Transit Account in the HTF was not penalized when the 2.5 cents was deposited into the General Fund.)  11  The total projected revenues to the Highway Account from transferring 2.5 cents per gallon of gasohol tax revenue now deposited into the General Fund are estimated at $4.1 billion over the six years of the act. It is further estimated that if the 2.5 cents were attributed to the HTF, Minnesota would receive an   additional $11 million during FFY2003. b. Equalize the federal gasohol tax with that of gasoline by 5.3 cents per gallon by transferring an equivalent amount from the General Fund - Gasohol is federally taxed at a rate that is 5.3 cents per gallon less than gasoline. Mn/DOT supports the use of alternative fuels from economic and environmental perspectives, however, gasohol powered vehicles contribute to the same amount of wear and tear on the roads as gasoline powered vehicles. If federal ethanol production subsidies are necessary to support alternative fuel usage, they should be provided out of the General Fund and not at the expense of the HTF. It is estimated that over the six years of the act, capturing this 5.3 cents per gallon would generate approximately $8 billion. If gasoline and gasohol were taxed evenly, it is estimated that Minnesota would receive approximately $33 million more in federal funding for FFY 2003. 4) Creating new financial mechanisms such as a federally chartered Transportation Finance Corporation In order to close the sizable funding gap between transportation investment needs and projected resources in the HTF, AASHTO has  developed the concept of establishing the Transportation Finance Corporation, a new tax credit bond program. The TFC would be a Congressionallychartered, private, non-profit organization that would act as the issuer of the bonds. It is anticipated that the budgetary cost of the program would be paid from additional HTF receipts from new net sources of revenue. Over the life of the next authorization period, $19.3 billion could be leveraged into $34.1 billion for highways and $8.5 billion for transit. The TFC proposal has the potential to generate the revenues necessary to grow the transportation program to levels identified as the minimum needed, but comes with fundamental philosophical changes to federal transportation funding. The TFC would change the accepted practice of "pay-as-yougo" for federal funding to a longterm bond program based on anticipated new receipts. The sources of these receipts need to be further explored to determine the viability of this concept. The following chart identifies the potential revenue generated by each option.
