Security Issues Overview The heightened threat of terrorism has introduced new security imperatives to the nation's highway and transit programs. While surface transportation infrastructure is robust and redundant, the consequences, both direct and indirect, of a large-scale attack could be significant. Roads, bridges, rail lines and waterways are the lifeblood of America and critical to economic vitality, particularly to Minnesota. Surface transportation infrastructure is important not only from the economic and mobility perspective but also for its emergency response utility in the context of a terrorist event on or off the system as witnessed in the September 11, 2001 events. All levels of government have responsibility to minimize the vulnerability of critical infrastructure assets and to prepare for transportation's role in emergency response and recovery. Additionally, there exists a need for improved capabilities to manage traffic during major events. Security issues will need to be considered for all aspects of the next federal transportation program. Mn/DOT supports the following AASHTO positions related to new security initiatives: 1) General security provisions The potential for the freight transportation system to be used as an element in a terrorism attack is based on clear precedent. Trucks can be used to transport weapons to targets or hijacked as weapons in and of themselves and containers can be used to smuggle weapons of mass destruction across borders. The large number of truck and container movements in combination with loosely controlled operator licensing and relatively open international borders presents a complicated mix for security. Currently, largely manual security screening methods are being used at borders, causing significant delays and added costs. The broader security challenge relates to tracking and credentialing for cargo security. The federal government is cooperating with a range of private entities to develop deployable sealing, tagging and tracking technology that can be applied, initially to hazardous materials vehicles and ultimately to all containers. Safety credentialing efforts now underway may, over time, require a security element as well. The federal intelligent transportation systems' commercial vehicle program (CVISN) could provide useful technology for these efforts. Mn/DOT's perspective is that cargo security measures are likely to result in improvements in cargo tracking, handling, and delivery as a byproduct. Congress should authorize a moderate increase and broadened eligibility in existing Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration federal-aid highway programs to support security activities (assuming that overall highway program funding is substantially above TEA-21 levels) as well as significant general funding from the Department of Homeland Security. The implication for Minnesota would be developing and implementing security-related activities in addition to those for safety. Commercial motor vehicle security should be a distinct and focused planning activity included in the program areas of those agencies dealing directly with credentialing, inspecting and auditing commercial motor vehicles and operators, motor carriers, shippers, freight brokers and hazardous material storage facilities. Additional or separate funding could specifically enhance projects dealing with cargo, vehicle, driver, shipper  13   security awareness, roadside screening and enforcement, enhanced data interchange and credentialing verification. It could fund technologies and programs that help states partner with local jurisdictions to monitor suspicious commercial motor vehicle activity that may pose a security threat. Such technologies could include X-ray screening machines and high-resolution imaging equipment that would be used at weigh scales and border check facilities to scan for contraband or weapons. It is appropriate to meet these objectives using emerging ITS technologies and improved cooperation between the public and private sectors and between DOTs and law enforcement. Also, funding for training such as the "Terrorism and Trucks - Rapid Risk Recognition, Assessment and Response Seminar/Workshops", etc., should be made available. Congress should direct that federal agencies provide an expedited environmental and planning process for security-related projects. Additionally, Congress should separate the statewide and metropolitan planning factors for safety and security into two distinct factors - one for safety and one for security. 2) Asset protection While the surface transportation system is characterized by a high degree of resilience and redundancy, there are critical metropolitan mobility links and critical national system links whose loss would have serious implications. The Federal Highway Administration, in cooperation with state departments of transportation, has conducted a process to identify critical transportation links above and beyond those associated with Department of Defense needs. Asset protection goes beyond bridges and tunnels, where damage would disrupt basic mobility. The broad array of assets includes those that may be directly  threatened, but also includes assets that might be instrumental or used as a weapon. Threatened assets include infrastructure (including bridges and tunnels), facilities (rest stops, border crossings, storage areas), equipment (vehicles, devices) and staff. No federal standards for vulnerability assessment, protective actions or infrastructure hardening have been developed. Individual state DOTs have undertaken protective measures that they judge sufficient, based on their own assessment of criticality and vulnerability, and have carried out such improvements without special federal funding. It is Mn/DOT's position that federal vulnerability assessment guidelines should be established as a "minimum standard" and that funding be available to regularly update/revise those guidelines. New protection program for critical, security-related infrastructure, facilities and equipment - Congress should authorize (drawing from the General Fund) a new program through the Department of Homeland Security for critical infrastructure/facility asset external protection (patrolling, camera surveillance, detection) of critical, security-related facilities (e.g., bridges and tunnels). Minnesota uses a significant level of surveillance and detection, including its use in tunnels and on bridges. Expansion of these systems or hardening of such facilities would require new federal funding. Any security-related surveillance or detection system must be integrated into the overall transportation system to ensure continued operation and maintenance of such systems when the perception of a security threat is low. That is, such systems must provide security plus enhanced traffic operations. Implement structural hardening and other measures - Congress should provide for state-selected structural  "It is Mn/DOT's position that federal vulnerability assessment guidelines should be established as a "minimum standard" and that funding be available to regularly update/revise those guidelines."  14   "Mn/DOT believes that increase federal-aid highway funding for security activities such as detection, surveillance, traffic control, and traveler information improvements is critical."  hardening and other security-related structural measures for new or reconstructed facilities through increased funding in the core federal-aid highway programs (National Highway System, Interstate, Bridge). Additional facility issues - The most difficult to fund will be those initiatives which ultimately lead to greater security at remote facilities where materials and equipment could be used for a terrorist attack (e.g., a Mn/DOT truck). There is typically little in the way of surveillance/security at these facilities. The same is true at rest stops. These areas could be used as a marshalling yard by people wishing to do harm. 3) Emergency response preparation The emergency response activities of state departments of transportation take place within an established federal/state emergency management institutional framework. While most emergencies start as local, major emergencies quickly become state- or multi-state declared emergencies. State departments of transportation and local governments participate in state emergency management agency-led activities as a support function within a formal framework established by the statewide emergency management plan. Following a model established by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, these are "all-hazard" plans and generally define the authorities, chain of command, communications protocols and specific areas of responsibility of various agencies. Some state emergency management plans have specific components dealing with natural and industrial disaster responses. s  general funds to support continuing emergency response preparedness planning, training and special weapons of mass destructionrelated protection equipment for surface transportation, including transit. It is Mn/DOT's position that adequate funding for emergency preparedness is essential in order to provide state and local agencies the necessary resources above and beyond current operational demands. s  Increase federal-aid highway funding for security, hazardous materials and safety-related incident response and management. In order to support security, hazardous material and safety-related incident response and management, Congress should increase Highway Trust Fund funding with $500 million per year being directed to these activities. The activities that would be funded include detection, surveillance, traffic control and traveler information improvements for application on critical freeways and arterials, on and off the National Highway System and on critical transit facilities. This increase would be apportioned through existing categories of funding and could only be spent on projects and activities that are consistent with the security components of the statewide longrange transportation plan. Mn/DOT believes that increase federal-aid highway funding for security activities such as detection, surveillance, traffic control, and traveler information improvements is critical.  15  Provide new General Fund resources for emergency preparedness. Congress should enable access to $100 million annually in Department of Homeland Security or Federal Emergency Management Agency  s  Provide first responders with access to communications funding. Congress should enable state DOTs, together with other first responder associations, to have access to Department of Justice, Department of Homeland Security or Federal   Emergency Management Agency general funds for development of improved nationally-standard, interoperable and hardened communications for interagency (police, fire, security, emergencymedical, transportation) communications. s  Case studies of various "disasters" show that it is always communication that breaks down thereby hampering an agency's ability to respond effectively. Integration and interoperability of communications systems among various agencies is key to success and should be strongly supported. In Minnesota, the Department of Public Safety has a coordinating role in the event of an emergency situation. It is also recognized and accepted that local law enforcement would have primary jurisdiction depending upon the location and magnitude of the emergency. Many Minnesota ITS activities would benefit from this proposal. Communications now used for traffic signals, message signs, meters, etc. are not hardened. Communications hardening would have to be defined and implemented on new projects.  16   Safety Issues Overview "Safety is and will remain a priority for Minnesota." A quarter century of progress in decreasing highway deaths began to slow in the early 1990s. During the past decade, between 530 and 650 Minnesotans died annually in highway crashes. Although government agencies, safety advocates and the automotive industry have introduced many initiatives, progress has been slowed. In response, Mn/DOT has implemented a number of targeted, highly efficient, low-cost safety improvement strategies, primarily involving infrastructure such as rumble strips and improved signage and pavement markings. Other state safety interests have focused on drinking and driving, improved driver education programs and stronger seat belt legislation. Safety is and will remain a priority for Minnesota. The next federal transportation bill should include enhanced safety planning, flexible funding for infrastructure improvements and support for application of effective low-cost safety improvement strategies. The increase in motor carrier and commercial vehicle traffic at the nation's borders since the passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement has increased concerns about safety. Both the federal government and state agencies have taken steps to implement aggressive inspection programs to ensure that all such vehicles meet safety standards. Mn/DOT supports the following positions that address safety improvement issues: 1) s  being directed to safety-oriented roadway improvements and other safety activities. This increased funding would be apportioned through all existing categories of funding and could only be spent on projects and activities that are consistent with the safety component of the statewide longrange plan. This strategy is consistent with Mn/DOT's Statewide Transportation Plan performance targets. Continued safety improvements at railroad - highway grade crossings is important in Minnesota. Stable or increased funding is necessary due to the increased cost of physical safety improvements at crossings and potential train/vehicular conflicts are increasing with growth in traffic volumes, particularly on high density freight lines. s  Highway safety funding Increase funding: In order to support a policy to significantly reduce fatalities on the nation's highways, Congress should increase Highway Trust Fund by $1 billion per year of the additional funds s  Increase effectiveness of safety setaside funding: Congress should direct several improvements to increase the effectiveness of the Surface Transportation Program's 10 percent safety set-aside. Specifically, Congress should direct that funds be used exclusively to implement the state's comprehensive highway safety plan. Safety set-aside funds should be used consistently with the proposed comprehensive highway safety component of the state's transportation plan. States should also be given greater flexibility to transfer funding among the subcategories. NHTSA safety funding: NHTSA administers a series of safety grant programs. These programs have differing goals and guidelines. Examples include the Section 402 community highway safety grants as well as the grants offered  17   through Sections 405 (occupant protection), 410 (alcohol-impaired driving counter measures), 411 (state highway data improvement) and 2003(b) (child passenger protection education) and the Sections 157 (safety belts) and 163 (anti-drunk driving) grant programs. Congress should consolidate several safety grant programs into a single, flexible Section 402 highway safety program that would be goaloriented and risk-based. Although in Minnesota the Section 402 funds go directly to the Department of Public Safety, Mn/DOT needs to be involved in deciding safety strategies and the state needs to retain program flexibility. 2) Support of state and local safety statues TEA-21 includes a restriction on use of funds for certain lobbying activities. This provision prohibits the Secretary of Transportation from engaging in "any activity designed to urge a State or local legislator to favor or oppose the adoption of any specific legislative proposal pending before any state or local legislative body." The current restrictions limit the ability of transportation officials to advocate on behalf of new safety proposals, effectively compromising their ability to lend their professional expertise to the debates over these issues. Mn/DOT believes it is appropriate that the state's safety experts be allowed to testify and provide information to elected officials. Freeing transportation officials to enter into the discussions about these issues would benefit legislators by providing them with quality professional advice.  3) Motor carrier safety s  Motor Carrier Safety Assistance Program: Congress should provide additional funding, from sources other than the Highway Trust Fund, for the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration's Motor Carrier Safety Assistance Program (MCSAP). Higher MCSAP funding will enable the FMCSA to promote detection and correction of commercial motor vehicle safety defects, commercial motor vehicle driver deficiencies and unsafe motor carrier practices before they become contributing factors to crashes and hazardous materials incidents. An increase in funding would enable Minnesota to provide additional educational and technical assistance, deploy new safety initiatives and improve data exchange. Mn/DOT's Office of Motor Carrier Services currently participates in the MCSAP safety program along with the Minnesota State Patrol's Commercial Vehicle Section. The basic operating grant requires a 20 percent match by the state agency for any MCSAP activity it conducts. If the basic grant were to increase to 100 percent federal funding, it would provide Minnesota greater flexibility to develop, initiate, and maintain specific safety programs and products. If 100 percent basic grant funding were offered, Minnesota could specifically promote or enhance interagency and multi-jurisdictional partnerships; provide easier and coordinated exchange of data and information of carrier/shipper/operator history to roadside enforcement from multiple jurisdictions; expand efforts that endorse, create and maintain uniform and cooperative arrangements on a regional scale to  "If 100 percent basic grant funding were offered, Minnesota could specifically promote or enhance interagency and multi-jurisdictional partnerships, providing easier and coordinated exchange of data and information."  18   improve data flow and safety information exchange across state borders; and provide training to Mexican and new-entrant US and Canadian carriers. s  Safety monitoring program: Congress should establish a safety monitoring program for Mexican motor carriers and all new entrant U.S. and Canadian-based carriers. A comprehensive North American safety-monitoring program would target resources at those less experienced carriers that would be at higher risk of safety violations. An increase in funding would enable Minnesota to increase training resources that would target the less experienced carriers in hopes of establishing a solid safety foundation. Mn/DOT's Office of Motor Carrier Services currently has a mandated training program for new Minnesota intrastate carriers called IMCC (Initial Motor Carrier Contact). This training was developed to educate carriers on commercial motor vehicle and driver safety requirements. The IMCC program could be modified to conform to FMCSA standards. If given additional resources, it could be given to new interstate entrants.  19   Freight Transportation Issues Overview During the past two decades, freight transportation by all modes has experienced tremendous growth. The value of freight and cargo moved by truck, rail, and air has skyrocketed. Ecommerce has contributed to expanded freight movements and turned transportation infrastructure virtually into moving warehouses. It is estimated that even modest economic growth will double the volume of export/import tonnage and increase domestic tonnage by 70 percent in the next twenty years. These increases have taxed the capacity of our ports, rail lines, highways, and airports. As a result congestion, capacity constraints, shipping delays and service reliability are increasing the cost of freight transportation. Without increased investment in infrastructure, innovative financing, flexible funding, and improved operational efficiency, the competitive advantage Minnesota and the nation have with global markets will erode. Mn/DOT supports the following AASHTO positions related to freight transportation: 1) Financing Congress should support the use of existing innovative finance tools and new financing mechanisms for investments in freight transportation infrastructure. In the aggregate, the need for investment in freight transportation infrastructure is substantial. It is neither possible nor appropriate to meet this need through standard sources of public investment. Existing financing mechanisms should be amended to and new mechanisms should be developed to increase investment in freight transportation projects: q TIFIA should be amended to lower the project threshold, expand eligibility for freight projects and relax repayment requirements. TIFIA eligibility requirements need to be softened, especially the $100 million threshold. This framework reflects significant changes in the transportation planning process that have strengthened stakeholder and public involvement, established multimodal planning processes and are sensitive to a multitude of factors from environmental, economic development and improved access to transportation facilities and services. While the planning processes within states and metropolitan areas are generally sound and should be retained, improvements can be made to improve efficiency and responsiveness to comply with new requirements and not hamper planning process improvements gained in the past decade. Federal planning requirements should continue to exhibit flexibility as no two states or metropolitan areas face the same issues. States need to be able to work with constituent groups to find the best solutions to specific situations. Financial planning can also be enhanced through increased flexibility in federal requirements as can state long-range plans. Many in the transportation community consider Minnesota a model for cooperative, progressive planning and financial decision making with regional and local governments. The relationship with other units of governments has served the citizens of Minnesota well. That said, Minnesota shares the same concerns related to flexibility and program/process streamlining to help deliver projects more quickly and efficiently. In terms of program flexibility, Mn/DOT supports the following reauthorization proposals:  Update Cycle for Metropolitan Long Range Transportation Plans TEA-21 requires that each Metropolitan Planning Organization (MPO) develop a Long Range Transportation Plan (LRP) with a minimum 20-year forecast period. Metropolitan planning provisions in TEA-21 establish general guidelines for MPOs, state departments of transportation (DOTs), and transit agencies to follow in updating MPO plans. The FHWA requires these updates every three years. A five-year cycle would be much more meaningful than an arbitrary three-year cycle. In Minnesota, three of the MPOs (Twin Cities, Duluth and St. Cloud) are maintenance areas and therefore must currently update their long-range plans every three years. The Twin Cities MPO typically updates its long-range transportation plan following an update of the regional blueprint. The blueprint sets out the overall development and policy framework for the region. Another benchmark for updating the transportation long-range plan is revising the transportation model following compilation of new census data and travel behavior data, which occurs every ten years.  "Another benchmark for updating the transportation long-range plan is revising the transportation model following compilation of new census data and travel behavior data, which occurs every ten years."  Fiscal Constraint in State and Metropolitan Plans and TIPS TEA-21 included requirements of financial constraint for State Transportation Improvement Programs (STIPs), and MPO Transportation Improvement Programs (TIPs). The intent of these requirements was to match project commitments to overall resources at the planning level. The states have responded to these requirements and no longer include projects in STIPs/TIPs that they can't afford to finance. Modal Planning ISTEA and TEA-21 introduced a multimodal focus, although funding was still largely limited to highways and transit. Infrastructure and operational needs of the various modes are important, as is the way they interact with each other. Of increasing concern to state DOTs and MPOs are the safe integration and interaction of multiple users on the same system, or the interface between systems such as rail/highway grade crossings or NHS connections to multimodal terminals. During reauthorization, Congress should recognize the ability of state DOTs and MPOs to respond to the needs of their constituents and the legitimate role of state DOTs and MPOs in decision making on connections to the NHS or other highway facilities by ports, airports and freight terminals. Currently there are limitations on Mn/DOT and the MPOs for planning over ports, airports, and freight terminals. The freight industry is primarily privately owned and their freight movements have an impact on public infrastructure that the state and MPOs do not control. Thus Mn/DOT's and MPOs' ability to respond to the needs of their constituents, including those who use other than highway and transit modes, need to be retained and expanded.  State Long Range Transportation Plans Title 23 requires that each state develop a state long range transportation plan with a minimum 20-year forecast period. Statewide planning provisions in TEA-21 establish general guidelines for state DOTs to follow including the consideration of seven planning factors, which cover a broad range of transportation issues that have varying degrees of applicability to various states. State plans vary in scope and purpose across the country and reflect each State's individual transportation planning needs as well as each state's individual vision, goals and objectives for transportation. Mn/DOT's position is that Congress should continue to provide flexibility to states as to content of Long Range Plans, performance measures, and planning horizons so long as a minimum of a 20-year horizon is maintained.  Different Frequency Requirement for Transportation Plan and Conformity Updates Transportation plans must be updated every three years. Transportation Improvement Programs (TIPs) must be updated every two years. In addition, there are various SIP-related triggers in the transportation conformity rule that require plan and TIP updates within 18 months of various SIP actions. State Implementation Plans (SIPs) do not have a regular update cycle.  27   In Minnesota, three MPOs (Twin Cities, Duluth and St. Cloud) are currently required to update their long-range plans every three years as maintenance areas. This can be burdensome and not necessarily consistent with the availability of new data or the regional development plan. Different Planning Horizons for Transportation and Air Quality Plans Metropolitan transportation plans are required to have a minimum of a 20year planning horizon. State Implementation Plans (SIPs) are for a period that extends to the attainment date with the latest being 2010. Mn/DOT's position is that improved alignment of time frames for transportation and air quality planning horizons would streamline the process and should be supported.  Conformity Requirements after Maintenance Period Conformity requirements currently apply to non-attainment and maintenance areas. Some areas are approaching the end of the 20-year maintenance period. Yet, since these areas are still maintenance areas, they are required to do conformity analysis for the complete period of the transportation plan, which may extend far beyond the end of the maintenance period. Congress should clarify that conformity requirements apply only to the end of the maintenance period. In Minnesota, the Twin Cities became a maintenance area in 1999. Duluth and St. Cloud are both in the eighth year of their maintenance periods and are currently in the process of updating their maintenance plans with the Minnesota Pollution Control Agency. When the Twin Cities next updates its long range plan by November 2004, the plan will cover 2005-2030, while the conformity requirements will end with 2019. Clarification of the application of conformity in the long-range plans compared to the duration of the maintenance periods would be helpful.  28   "Minnesota needs to be able to implement common-sense approaches and allocate funds where they are most needed."  Interjurisdictional and Institutional Issues Overview States provide a central role in the development of the surface transportation system, even as other jurisdictions and institutions, local governments, metropolitan planning organizations, tribal governments and federal agencies themselves, have come to play important parts. The current decision-making structure that recognizing the state's leadership in the development of transportation plans, programs and projects is essential in delivering a comprehensive transportation system in Minnesota. TEA-21 recognizes that the federal highway program is a "federally assisted state program" and it is important that Congress maintain and reaffirm the state's leadership role and authority in reauthorization. Unfunded mandates and unwarranted sanctions reduce the state's discretion and resources available and the ability to respond effectively to transportation needs. Minnesota needs to be able to implement common-sense approaches and allocate funds where they are most needed. Mn/DOT supports the following positions related to interjurisdictional and institutional issues: 1) Decision-making authority The statewide transportation planning process focuses on longestablished institutional relationships between different governmental entities for decisions on plans, programs and project selection. These relationships were formalized with the enactment of ISTEA, and continued under TEA21. The existing transportation planning process, the result of a decade's worth of experience in creating collaborative models for involvement by all levels of government, has proven successful. The public interest has been well served by the present balance of responsibilities between the federal, state and local levels of government, and by the processes and procedures that have been put in place accordingly. The current model of ATP decision making in Minnesota has served the state well. Mn/DOT and local government partners would support retaining the existing balance of authority. To truly have decisions made around "true needs," we do not support new set-asides. If the maximum percentage of federal funds per project is reduced below 80 percent, some agencies will have difficulty matching with local dollars along with the added requirements of a federal project. Congress should continue TEA-21's decision-making, processes and procedures for transportation planning, programming and project selection. This means retaining the balance of decision making between states and MPOs and states and rural officials; retaining the current definitions of planning "consultation, cooperation and coordination" and meeting needs through the existing program structure, rather than through new set-asides. 2) Statewide planning process Title 23 requires that each state develop a state long-range transportation plan with a minimum 20-year forecast period. Statewide planning provisions in TEA-21 establish general guidelines for state departments of transportation to follow including consideration of seven statewide planning factors. The seven factors cover a broad  29   range of transportation issues that have varying degrees of applicability to each state. Current proposals for changes to the planning process in reauthorization include a 25-year planning horizon, more frequent updates of plans and measures to require greater accountability on the part of states. It is Mn/DOT's position that Congress should protect state discretion, flexibility, innovation and accountability in the statewide planning process while affirming the importance of the federal-aid highway program's transportation mission, specifically: q Congress should provide maximum flexibility to the states to apply the statewide planning provisions and interact with MPOs and extra-MPO organizations, as well as pursue creative solutions while honoring and striving to achieve the intent of the federal legislation. q Congress should retain the following statutory provisions that protect state discretion and ensure state level flexibility, innovation and accountability. q Congress should confirm in statute the requirement for state concurrence in the planning and selection of public lands highway projects, including forest highways. q Congress should ensure that federal statutes continue to defer to state and local governments on whether and how to consider land use in the course of transportation planning. q Congress should ensure that federal statutes support balanced transportation investment strategies that are based on statewide and metropolitan planning processes. Congress should support the concept that preservation of the existing system involves more than pavement preservation, including  enhancing safety and modernizing highways and transit to bring them up to current design standards. q Congress should reaffirm the primary transportation mission of the federal highway program while acknowledging support for multiple policy goals. Congress should oppose revisions to federal law that impose new cost components that detract from the primary transportation mission. 3) International ports of entry The enactment of the North American Free Trade Agreement, and unprecedented economic growth in North America during the past decade, are driving factors in the rapid expansion of trade between the United States, Mexico and Canada. In an increasingly global economy, it is critical that the flow of people, goods and commerce across international borders be as efficient as possible. Yet, the movement across borders is often beyond the control of transportation agencies to affect. Inadequate federal inspection staffing levels at many international ports of entry and the lack of coordination between federal inspection agencies and federal and state transportation agencies results in increased congestion and delays at international ports of entry. New security requirements at international ports of entry may result in long traffic delays causing major economic costs to shippers and businesses dependent on timesensitive deliveries as well as major impacts on local economies dependent on cross border passenger travel for tourism, recreation and entertainment and other related businesses. This should not be allowed to become another drain on already short highway funds.  30   It is Mn/DOT's position that Congress should promote enhanced coordination with Mexican and Canadian officials to speed international ports of entry and modify eligibility for the Coordinated Border Infrastructure Discretionary Program to include publicly owned landside access facilities at seaports and international inland ports of entry. Congress should help speed the flow of traffic at international ports of entry by making it easier for states to transfer federal highway funds to non-transportation federal agencies implementing improvements, providing new, nontransportation federal funding for inspection activities and promoting greater coordination and efficiencies at border crossings.  31   Environmental Stewardship and Streamlining Issues Overview Achieving the goal of delivering better and faster transportation projects requires a dual commitment to environmental stewardship and streamlining. This commitment to environmental stewardship involves proactive efforts to include environmental mitigation and enhancements in new projects, wider use of environmentally sensitive maintenance and operations techniques and the use of technology to improve the linkages between planning and project development. In terms of streamlining, it is necessary for Congress to fix environmental review processes that too often fail to resolve conflicts that have delayed projects in the past. Help is needed to support transportation agencies efforts to ensure planning level decisions are not disregarded when the NEPA process begins. Help is needed to clarify agency roles and responsibilities in the NEPA process, so that it does not become bogged down in endless interagency disputes. Help is needed to restore a degree of flexibility and common sense to Section 4(f) review, while preserving its essential elements. With help in these areas and others, the environmental process can become faster and more efficient, while producing better outcomes for our transportation system and environment. Mn/DOT supports the following positions related to environmental stewardship and streamlining: 1) Stewardship initiatives Environmental stewardship is a voluntary commitment made by individual state DOTs at their own discretion to go beyond the minimums require by law. It is not a new set of regulatory requirements. Environmental stewardship is commitment to a "new way of doing business" that affects all activities within Mn/DOT. It is not a separate program or activity. Many activities that are being undertaken as part of environmental stewardship efforts are already eligible for Federal funding, under existing law. Congress can best promote stewardship by preserving existing funding flexibility, streamlining administrative procedures for projects that enhance the environment and supporting increased funding, training and outreach. This would accelerate parts of the current processes, provide more local control and increase funding. 2) Reforming the NEPA process The National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) process for large, complex projects has become increasingly lengthy and complex. Previous efforts to streamline the process, including those in TEA-21, have yielded some results, but significant problems remain. It is Mn/DOT's position that Congress should strengthen and expand the environmental streamlining provisions of TEA-21. Specifically establish in statue: q That U.S. DOT and state DOTs, as co-lead agencies in the NEPA process, have the authority to define purpose and need and determine the range of alternatives considered, for purposes of all federal reviews for a surface transportation project. q That other federal agencies participating in the NEPA process for a surface transportation project are responsible for early disclosure of concerns that could delay or  32   prevent permitting or other approvals, timely submittal of comments and due consideration of transportation goals when making permit decisions. q That the "purpose and need" in a NEPA document for a surface transportation project may be based on policy decisions made outside the NEPA process - e.g., in federal legislation, state and MPO transportation plans and local land use plans. q That the alternatives analysis in a NEPA document for a surface transportation project is sufficient if the document considers a "reasonable range of alternatives." Reasonableness should be determined by taking into account the overall the scope and complexity of the project and other relevant factors. q That the alternatives analysis in a NEPA document is sufficient if it considers each alternative in a "reasonable" level of detail for that alternative. Reasonableness should be determined by taking into account the overall scope and complexity of the project and other relevant factors. q "Default deadlines" that must be followed in the NEPA process, unless the lead agencies and other participating agencies reach agreement on alternative deadlines. Allow lead agencies to grant limited extensions to the deadlines for good cause. Additionally, modify the dispute resolution process to enable it to be invoked by a project applicant. That places the decision to invoke dispute resolution in hands of the project applicant; U.S. DOT is not the sole arbiter of when to invoke dispute resolution, as was the case under TEA-21 procedures proposed by USDOT in March 2001.  In Minnesota, these efforts would provide more local authority and responsibility, shorten the overall process and decisions would be made quicker. 3) Section 4(f) reforms Section 4(f) protects significant public-owned parks, recreation areas, wildlife refuges and all significant historic sites - whether publicly or privately owned. Section 4(f) prohibits the "use" of protected lands unless there is "no prudent and feasible alternative" and the selected alternative incorporates "all possible planning to minimize harm" to resources protected by Section 4(f). Section 4(f) has become an increasingly rigid, cumbersome statute as more properties are protected (especially historic properties) and even minor impacts trigger application of Section 4(f) - no exemptions allowed. Finally, Section 4(f) adds two years to the review process. It also increases project costs. Congress should reform Section 4 (f) to provide greater flexibility and reduce delays, while preserving protection for truly significant parks, recreational areas, wildlife refuges and historic sites. Mn/DOT supports a streamlined process with more flexibility that in turn will shorten project time frames, and is a more common sense approach to protecting environmental assets. 4) Time limits for legal claims Under current law, lawsuits challenging an FHWA or FTA decision can be filed for up to six years after the end of the NEPA process. By contrast, challenges to FAA decisions must be filed within a 60-day deadline. Major expenditures can be made in this six-year period for final design, right-of-way acquisition and even construction. When lawsuits are  33   filed long after the end of the NEPA process, they can cause unnecessary disruption - which easily could have been avoided if the legal actions had been filed promptly after the NEPA process ended. Requiring lawsuits to be filed within a defined period after the end of the NEPA process (e.g., 60 or 90 days) would fully preserve citizens' rights to bring legal challenges, while also achieving closure more quickly on any disputed issues. Therefore, it is Mn/DOT's position that Congress should establish a specific, reasonable time limit within which lawsuits could be filed challenging federal approvals for surface transportation projects. This approach would save money and time, because, once a decision is made, the ability to proceed will be able to be determined.  34   Research Issues Overview "Continued support for transportation research funding is strongly supported by Mn/DOT." Research is crucial to advances in transportation that can save lives, time and money. While overall funding for highways and transit has grown considerably in recent years, federal funding for research has barely grown at all. Federally supported planning and research programs have been a model of state, federal and other stakeholder cooperation in developing more durable road material, improving highway safety and increasing the reliability of travel times. They have led to socially, environmentally and economically responsible highway and transit development. Minnesota is considered a national leader in the area of transportation research. Mn/DOT in partnership with the University of Minnesota's Center for Transportation Studies and the Humphrey Institute continue the tradition of research and ultimately deployment of technologies that are improving the nation's transportation system. Continued support for transportation research funding is strongly supported by Mn/DOT. Specifically, Mn/DOT is supportive of the following national research positions: Maintain the State Planning and Research Program Congress should continue the State Planning and Research Program in its current, formula-based configuration (i.e., 2 percent of federal-aid programs, with a 25 percent minimum for research). Any reduction in SPR funds will be devastating for Minnesota and other states research program. Initiate F-SHRP Congress should authorize the Future Strategic Highway Research Program and appropriate $75 million annually for six years using a set-aside of a percentage of all federal-aid highway apportionments in fiscal years 2004 through 2009. The Future Strategic Highway Research Program will be a specialpurpose, time-constrained research program in which a concentration of resources is used to accelerate progress toward a few, high-priority objectives. The F-SHRP program would focus on four goals: renewal of America's highways; significant improvement in highway safety; reliable travel times; and environmentally, economically and socially responsive highway development Increase funding for FHWA national research priorities Congress should increase funding for the FHWA's research program to approximately $300 million annually, which is $98.5 million above current levels. This should include funding for a new Surface Transportation Environmental Cooperative Research Program at $15 million annually. Funding at a level nearly 50 percent above current appropriations will ensure that the Federal Highway Administration has sufficient resources to carry out its research programs and restore funding to pre-TEA-21 levels. Complete Long-Term Pavement Performance Program (LTPP) To derive full benefit from the member departments' investment in the LTPP program, Congress should sustain this component of the Strategic Highway Research Program through 2009 to complete the process at an estimated cost of $20 million annually. This would be part of, and not in addition to,  35   the FHWA's research and technology funds. Increased effort will also be needed in data analysis and product development if the expectations for LTPP are to be met. The LTPP Advisory Committee estimates that $120-125 million will be required to support the work of the LTPP studies from fiscal years 2004 through 2009. Support transit research Congress should reverse the steady decline in Transit Cooperative Research Program (TCRP) funding. Funds for the program should be authorized and appropriated at $15 million annually. Future levels should be based on a formula that ties program funding to the level of transit funding. During the last five fiscal years (FFY 1997-2001), a total of 539 problem statements were submitted for TCRP funding. Based on the funding available, 22, or 4 percent, were selected. The TCRP project selection process is not only highly competitive, but under funding results in many important transit research needs going unmet. University Transportation Centers (UTC) Congress should increase funding for UTCs from the current level of $32 million annually to $50 million annually. This program is funded from - and is not in addition to - the budget from FHWA, R&T and FTA research. Ten regional consortia (66 universities) were selected based on competition in 1988 and funded at $1 million per year. Their funding has not been increased. In addition, Congress has added 23 other universities since then.  Promote focused safety research programs Dependent upon an increase in overall program levels, Congress should increase funding for the safety research programs supported by the Highway Trust Fund at the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) and the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA). The programs should be increased from approximately $10 million annually to $30 million annually for FMCSA and from $16.3 million annually to $25 million annually for NHTSA. The programs should be focused on continuing to help reduce fatalities and injuries. The NHTSA and the FMCSA are responsible for the safety of large vehicles whose size and carrying capacity make their crashes potentially catastrophic. Their safety programs, focused on reducing collisions, fatalities and injuries, are a crucial element of all surface transportation safety efforts.  36   Operations/Intelligent Transportation Systems Issues "Minnesota is nationally and internationally recognized as a leader in the research, and deployment of ITS technologies." It is now widely recognized that providing an effective highway-based transportation system consists of three primary components - building the necessary infrastructure, preserving that infrastructure and operating and managing the system on a day-to-day basis. ITS has emerged as a critical means to achieving a broader set of goals (security, safety, reliability) in serving transportation users. Intelligent Transportation Systems play an important role in ensuring the security of America's transportation system and in facilitating post-disaster emergency response and evacuation. Using tools, technology and institutions working together to achieve security, safety and reliability for the user drives operating the system. Each of the initiatives and proposals is designed to make significant progress to creating a national network of system operations. The goal is to invest once to achieve maximum utility for the highway, transit, public safety and emergency response communities as they serve the public and user. Minnesota is nationally and internationally recognized as a leader in the research, and deployment of ITS technologies. Mn/DOT's educational, research and private sector partners continue to develop and utilize ITS programs that are reshaping traditional DOT responsibilities that reflect a transportation system operational focus necessary today. To continue this role in the development and deployment of ITS systems, there are three primary ITS issue areas that TEA-21 reauthorization needs to address: Policy Initiatives The focus of the policy initiatives is to expedite the delivery of deployment projects, facilitate interjurisdictional cooperation and sharing to speed the process of needed standards and ensure appropriate performance reporting against established performance targets. Specifically, reauthorization needs to create and support approaches, which will significantly expedite the deployment of proven and focused ITS technologies; minimize or eliminate barriers in the federal program to the creation of new innovative institutions and relationships for cross-jurisdictional deployment; encourage the development of tools and techniques to improve the planning and procurement for ITS deployment; recognize that funding and regulatory models are needed to accommodate private sector performance of traditionally public sector activities. ITS Deployment The focus of deployment is strengthening the safety and security of the transportation system by deploying tools and partnerships that provide the maximum amount of sharing across jurisdictions of state and local government. Reauthorization should support innovative organizations and relationships for cross-jurisdictional planning and deployment of regional transportation system operations and management through the cooperation and collaboration of transportation, public safety and emergency response agencies at the federal, regional, state and local levels. Support the creation of a National Transportation Information Network that will link all existing and future metropolitan and rural transportation systems into an integrated yet distributed data network capable of collecting, sharing and archiving transportation system operation, traffic condition and performance information. The network should be the foundation for security monitoring, infrastructure management and operation, traveler  37   information, freight management, and other aspects of transportation enabling the seamless and secure movement of people and goods. Increase funding to plan and expedite deployment of proven systems, to support operations and to hire and train skilled staff to manage the systems. There are several ITS areas where continued deployment nationally is essential: q 511 systems with the goal of making 511 service available to 80 percent of the population by 2005. q Nationwide deployment and enhancement of CVISN to ensure that the functionality of the program is uniform throughout the country. It is also envisioned that it is capable of tracking and monitoring critical cargo and operator locations. Performance would be studied and appropriately implemented. q Road weather data gathering networks and National Incident Reporting System (CARS) are key to the success of achieving the new model of transportation systems. Operation with new technology provides the ability to monitor and collect information about what is happening on the system. * Metropolitan congestion relief and incident response systems have emerged to be critical functions shared between transportation, public safety and emergency response communities. These systems include communication, information dissemination and support for critical incident response and system monitoring and management. q Safety initiatives supporting transportation and public safety professionals need to convey the right information at the right time and place. That information must  often be shared across system, organizational and jurisdictional boundaries. Inter-operable procedures and technologies for public safety and transportation operations will enable this vision of integrated information for safer communities. ITS Research There remains a need for a strong intermodal research program to perform basic research. The program would develop, test and evaluate new tools and strategies; develop and maintain the national ITS architecture and ITS standards; and provide technical assistance, guidance and training to deploying agencies. Mn/DOT supports the following positions related to ITS research: q A continued federal role, in partnership with the public and private sectors, to develop architecture and standards that will enhance interoperability, integration capabilities, center-to-center data sharing and data dissemination to third parties. q A need to continue research and the development of additional securityrelated ITS technologies. q The continued development and implementation of education and training programs necessary to assure that transportation, safety, emergency response professionals are able to make use of the technologies for use in operations. Increase Intelligent Transportation Systems funding Congress should adjust funding for ITS research, standards and testing from the current level of $110 million annually to $125 million annually in order to maintain the current level of effort as an effective means of addressing many of the operational and safety challenges on the surface transportation network.  38   This level of funding is necessary to continue essential programs of research, standards development and testing, but also to provide for a substantially increased level of activities leading to preparation of state agencies and users for the actual widespread deployment of ITS technologies.  39

IPTA hears update on ADA issues By Peter Hallock Cheryl Hershey, from the Federal Transit Administration's Washington, D.C., Office of Civil Rights, spoke at the Iowa Public Transit Training Conference held June 6-9 in Sioux City. Hershey reviewed the general requirements for transportation providers under the Americans with Disabilities Act. She also discussed the growing number of legal actions taken by both the Federal Transit Administration (FTA) and the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) against local agencies that have failed to comply with the ADA rules. While she stated that the rules require full compliance with the various standards set forth in the rules, Hershey also indicated the courts have taken into consideration local officials' demonstrated efforts to reach full compliance. She pointed out it has been agencies which have consciously decided to aim for less than full compliance that have, to date, been the primary targets of legal action. Hershey noted that most investigations begin as a result of a public complaint to either FTA or DOJ. FTA will investigate the complaint and, if they find violations but no flagrantly willful noncompliance, will try to work with the local provider to reach compliance before resorting to legal action. She indicated it is also possible for a transportation provider to voluntarily request an assessment of their efforts, and her office can provide advice and assistance on questions that may come up in trying to meet the requirements. The Iowa Department of Transportation's Office of Public Transit and Iowa Public Transit Association jointly sponsored this training conference. In particular, TDM refers to strategies that aim to alleviate congestion by: 1) reducing demand for personal vehicle travel; 2) shifting personal vehicle trips away from congested corridors; and 3) shifting trips to high occupancy vehicles. More specifically, the Des Moines Area Metropolitan Planning Organization has adopted a congestion strategy that aims to reduce single occupancy vehicle trips to work by 10 percent. Known as TDM-10, this voluntary program's goal is to reduce trips, and hence congestion. One means of accomplishing this goal is to increase the percent of trips taken in high occupancy vehicles. Sverdrup Civil, who is serving the Iowa DOT as consultants, has subcontracted to Parsons Brinckerhoff, Quade & Douglas (PB) to, in part, assess transit initiatives that should be implemented to reduce congestion during reconstruction of I-235. One of the encouraging findings that Bryan Porter of PB has shared is that "...the structure is in place." Des Moines Metropolitan Transit Authority (MTA) has already established 10 service elements that constitute a foundation for building "...an effective TDM program." Elements of MTA's service that PB has identified as transit initiatives that are critical to the success of congestion management efforts include:  local routes that provide thorough coverage of the core area;  express and commuter services (including park and ride and a reverse commute route);  a downtown transit mall that focuses attention on transit;  an extensive system of downtown shuttles that provides midday mobility for bus and vanpool riders;  a system of transit passes with extensive third-party sales locations;  a well-developed program of employer incentives for transit and vanpool use, referred to by MTA as its Employer Support Program;  a "guaranteed ride home" program for vanpool and commuter bus riders;  a well established vanpooling program, known as Central Iowa Rideshare, that serves area commuters;  automated vehicle location (AVL) Intelligent Transportation technology is partially in place; and  fare payment "swipe card" technology, that is a payment option on Link services, could be expanded system wide to reduce boarding times. These elements of MTA's service will have a key role in reducing I-235 reconstruction traffic congestion because:  transit service is in place and, relative to roads, has more underused capacity; and  shifting work trips to transit actually removes vehicles from roads, while other measures under consideration may simply relocate congestion. Accordingly, MTA's management has undertaken a system redesign project aimed at determining how to best reconfigure its services. This project sought answers about how to improve transit service generally and, more specifically, what activities would best improve upon the elements identified by PB as being critical to the success of congestion mitigation strategies. Three of the 19 areawide transit service improvements identified have been determined to be both feasible and to hold real potential for easing traffic congestion related to I-235 reconstruction. They are:  improve on express services in suburbs currently receiving service, and expand to additional suburbs;  introduce high frequency cross-town service on at least the University Avenue corridor to reduce travel time and improve connectivity; and  introduce shuttle services to park-and-ride centers. In addition to these fixedroute service improvements, other transit measures that are viewed as essential to the success of TDM-10 strategies are:  expanding and improving employer support for, and expanding the fleet of, Central Iowa Rideshare;  fostering expanded and intensified employer participation in MTA's Employer Support Program, in which employers cover all or part of employee transit pass or vanpool fares; and  investigating implementation of "bus priority corridor" measures to improve the overall people-carrying capacity of certain streets (e.g., automated vehicle location hardware compatible with traffic signal controllers, bus priority at traffic signals through extended green, bus turnouts, and relocation of bus stops to the far side of selected intersections). "Recent investments by the MTA to upgrade its fixed-route and vanpool fleets have been made mindful of these TDM-10 strategies, and the DOT's commitment to develop multimodal alternatives has been a key to getting the community focused on this issue," said K. Stephen Spade, general manager, Des Moines Metropolitan Transit Authority. "However, additional federal, state and local funding is critical to the successful implementation of the TDM-10 Plan if stakeholders are to reach their goal of reducing vehicle trips by at least 2,200 trips per hour. Note the ducks in the foreground.  9   CONNECTIONS Iowa's student transportation rule drawing national attention By Peter Hallock Iowa's new rule on transporting students aboard regional transit buses has now been in place for one school year. The rule came about after the Iowa Public Transit Association asked the Iowa Legislature, during the 1999 session, to confirm and clarify the right of regional transit systems to carry student riders. The legislature did so, but also specified that the Iowa Department of Transportation should, in consultation with the Iowa Department of Education, establish administrative rules covering this practice. In drafting the rule, Iowa DOT worked with a committee that included the Iowa Department of Education, Iowa Public Transit Association, and Iowa Pupil Transportation Association. The group agreed to establish standards for driver qualification and training, vehicles, safety equipment, maintenance, and operating policies. There were minor issues that needed to be worked out in each of these areas, but the primary point of contention was over the vehicle standards. The school industry representatives mostly took the position that students could only be safely transported in a yellow school bus, while the transit community felt that transit vehicles could provide an equivalent level of safety. After considerable discussion, it came out that-- although a few Iowa transit systems were using some standard 15-passenger vans that everyone agreed were less safe--the transit systems had for many years voluntarily incorporated many school bus safety standards into their specifications for both modified vans and light-duty (bodyon-van-chassis) buses. This included the Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards (FMVSS) for vehicle rollover, joint strength and fuel system integrity. Nearly all Iowa transit vehicles bought since at least 1990, and many from before that, had been built to meet these standards in addition to all the normal safety standards for commercial buses. The primary differences then between transit buses and school buses are seating, color scheme, and features like the lights and stop arms. Iowa law prohibits vehicles other than school buses from being painted with the "school bus yellow" color scheme, and also prevents them from being equipped with stop arms and strobe lights like a school bus. On the seating issue, the school industry representatives preferred the school bus style seating which is highly padded and closely placed. The transit community pointed out this style of seats makes it difficult to serve adult riders comfortably. They also pointed to the benefits of training young persons in the use of seat and shoulder belts since they are standard safety equipment in all other types of vehicles and are now even starting to be required on school buses in some parts of the country. In the end, it was decided that regional public transit vehicles carrying students could either be equipped with school bus seating complying with FMVSS 222 or with standard seating, and crash protection/ seatbelt systems complying with FMVSS 207, 208, 209 and 210. One additional provision agreed to was that each new regional transit vehicle will be purchased with a rear emergency exit door. Although transit vehicles have emergency egress windows, and some also have escape roof hatches, the inclusion of rear emergency exit doors on all transit vehicles used for student transportation would be an added safety feature similar to what is used on many school buses in Iowa. Among the other new features of the rule were requirements to add to the driver training curricula, course work which would match up with annual school bus training sessions, and to have vehicles inspected twice a year by the Iowa Department of Education to ensure compliance with the vehicle and safety equipment parts of the rule. Now that Iowa regional transit systems have gotten through the first year under the rule with only minor friction over scheduling of inspections and definitions of compliant first aid kits, there is a real desire to see whether the Iowa model can be used in other parts of the country. Iowa DOT's Office of Public Transit staff were asked to make presentations concerning Iowa's student transportation rule at two recent national conferences for community transportation providers and for state departments of transportation. Participants in these conferences expressed considerable interest in seeing the federal rules on Head Start transportation changed to something more in line with Iowa's rule, particularly with regard to the vehicle requirements. (Head Start's current rule requires use of either school buses or "alternative vehicles" which are school buses without yellow coloring, stop arms and strobes, but with the high floors and the close-spaced school bus seating.)  10   CONNECTIONS  August  2001  Transit training library Feature video "Safe Transport of the Public Under ADA" A good video that can be used as part of your safety and education program for drivers is "Safe Transport of the Public Under ADA."
